q: Donald Rumsfeld 's camp has sniped before. But he goes a step further-- somewhat surprisingly so, for a self-styled loyal soldier-- and points a finger at George W. Bush as well. , on Thursday played down accounts of the break-in at the Museum and warned against`` rumours.'' In a posting on his blog( www.drZahi Hawass.com/blog/state-egyptian-antiquities-3-february-2011), Zahi Hawass said the incident at the museum resulted in 70 broken objects, all of which can be restored. `` I want people to know that after nine days of protests, the monuments are safe,'' Zahi Hawass said.`` If anything happens, I will announce it.'' had resulted in`` 70 broken objects, all of which can be restored.''`` I want people to know that after nine days of protests, the monuments are safe,'' Zahi Hawass said. If anything happens, I will announce it. He said firefighters had been deployed close to the museum to intervene as needed. His blog also featured pictures of heavily armed troops stationed at his office and behind the museum's high railings.

While Google resisted threats from rivals Yahoo! and Microsoft under Eric Schmidt , Larry Page will confront fiercer rivals, said Whit Andrews, an analyst at Gartner. Google versus Facebook is an order of magnitude more challenging, said Andrews. Competing with the social network for the attention of Web users will require new technology that differs from search, he said. Google co-founder Sergey Brin , 37, will focus on strategic projects,
